subject: Re: Pluggable Selector considered harmful? (Re: [junit] Re: Observations from a production use of JUnit4)
msgSnippet: ... Parameters ought to be named appropriately, but that s a topic for another group. ... Not if your refactoring tool operates on an AST. Nodes on the AST
messageBody:
On 02/06/2006 11:40 AM, Cédric Beust ♔ apparently said:
>
> I don't want to stray off topic too much, but I'd like to make two quick
> points in favor of static typing:
>
> - The value is not so much about robustness (I agree that mis-casts
> are rare) but about documentation. I do a lot of code reviews every
> day and
> I can tell you that reviewing Python or Ruby is an order of magnitude
> harder
> than reviewing Java because I can never tell what types are expected from
> method signatures.

Parameters ought to be named appropriately, but that's a topic for
another group.

>
> - Refactoring in dynamically typed languages is inherently unsafe.
> You can't even rename a method reliably. I'm glad it worked for you, but
> you need to keep in mind that renaming in a dynamically typed language is
> nothing more than a string replace. Use with caution.
>

Not if your refactoring tool operates on an AST. Nodes on the AST have
context which the refactoring tool should take into consideration.

--
Jason Rogers

Man shall not live by bread alone, but by every word that
proceedeth out of the mouth of God.
Matthew 4:4


(\ /)
